awd_titl_txt: DDIRG: Boundary-walkers: Insights into expertise and practices of translation between Indigenous knowledge and Western natural science
awd_abstract_narration:
Coping with environmental challenges requires recognizing and harnessing multiple forms of expertise to effectively manage environmental change. This dissertation project investigates the potential contributions of combining indigenous environmental knowledge with western science to better understanding and manage rapid environmental change. It combines archival data and data from in-depth interviews with Indigenous scientists who have strong cultural ties to their natal communities to explore the ways that these different perspectives can be hybridized and aligned to enable their combined use in environmental policy making. This project supports graduate student training, the inclusion of Native Americans in STEM fields, and find ways to use Indigenous knowledge to help ameliorate pressing environmental problems.

This project advances research within science and technology studies on hybrid forms of knowledge, scientific collaboration, and the science of policy making. It also advances efforts to promote environmental sustainability. The term “Boundary Walkers’ is used to describe natural scientists who are Indigenous and who have access to indigenous forms of environmental knowledge. Investigators seek to understand how Western and Indigenous knowledge systems can work together to confront problems arising from rapid environmental change, how boundary-walkers navigate across this divide, and how this knowledge can be put to practical use in environmental policy making. Data come from archives at universities, museums, and tribal libraries and associations, and from in-depth interviews with 30 boundary walkers. Overall, this original research provides pathways forward for integrating diverse forms of knowledge for practical good.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We interviewed 35 Indigneous scientists and produced deidentified transcripts. The discourse and themes analysis conducted for this study results yielded results which answered the research questions. Question 1: What is the nature of the gap between these two cultural knowledge systems is answered in Chapter 2 The Nature of the Gap. Question 2 How do the interviewees navigate, mediate, and work - both cognitively and practice-wise - across these two very different knowledge systems is answered primarily in Chapter 4 Community Based Epistemic Practice. Question 3: How do the two cultural knowledge systems (Western natural science and Indigenous knowledge) work together to modify the nature of their own expertise and Question 4 How do  the interviewees understand the emerging nature of blended expertise is answered in Chapter 3 The Ethos of Expertise and Chapter 6. Chapter 5 Cumulative Disadvantage discusses several differnent themes which can be catagorized under this heading. It includes discussion on multigenerational trauma, imposter syndrome, misrecognition, misrepresentation, racism, isolation, and perceptions of invisibility. It captures the difficulty Native American scientists have to face and overcome when practicing science. Chapter 6 The Journey to Identity - Boundarywalkers discusses the characteristics and ethos of science practiced by Native American scientists. It reframes the ethos typically upheld within Western scientific communities (value free objectivity) to an ethos that represents the standpoint of Native Americans

A significant result of this discourse analysis was the gentle challenging of Indigenous separation metaphors/mechanisms such as “Two-Eyed Seeing” and/or “Two Rivers Wampum”. The overwhelming majority of interviewees asserted that it is an inaccurate assumption to make a binary distinction between themselves as a (Western trained) scientist and an Indigenous person. Instead the interviewees assert that these two socially powerful cultures, characterized by their own dominant practices, configurations and structures of power and knowledge, are indistinguishable within themselves, and the identity and situated knowledge which results is unique. 

The research refers to someone who operates within this unique situated space of knowledge, as a Boundarywalker and the practice of using this unique situated knowledge to bridge the gap between cultures and/or knowledges as Boundarywalking. Descriptively, it is similar to Anita Wilson’s discussion of borderland discourse as a,  “third space culture which is neither one nor the other, but built out of elements of both.” But unlike Wilson’s third space, Boundarywalking has intentionality and heroicness. Every single one of the interviewees talked about a journey within themselves. They didn’t become a Boundarywalker simply through the powerful social constructs of these two external cultures pressing them. They have and exercise agency and ultimately choose this unique space of situated knowledge after a journey of self-reflexion. After evaluating both cultures and rationalizing a combined set of values built out of elements of both, they emerge from their journey as an integrated identity and they comprehend the power and importance of this unique space of situated knowledge. They also understand that making the decision to reside in this third space will subject them to a life of invisibility, double-othering, and generally not feeling completely accepted in either social structure. Additionally they will most likely be overworked or overextended simply because they are driven not just by their scientific work but also by a desire to support their tribal communities, a constant vigilance towards ethics, and a need to create change. They choose this identity because they understand the importance of their unique standpoint. Boundarywalkers  are conduits of more socially just and democratic science as well as tools for tribes to maximize sovereignty and resilience by having trustworthy access to global scientific knowledge.

 

Understanding interactions between knowledge system experts could contribute to a better approach to climate science and more integrative and effective adaptation strategies. Specifically, this research will: 1) provide a broader understanding of the emerging nature of expertise required to respond to changing Earth temporalities; 2) provide techniques for overcoming thought structures which co-produced the current climate crisis; 3) provide ways of recognizing and blending expertise from multiple knowledge systems; 4) provide a basis for funding of interdisciplinary science research directed at climate change adaptation strategies which embrace not only a plurality of knowledges but also a framework of translation which bridges cognitive dissonance between knowledges; 5) empower Indigenous scientists and their communities to influence climate change policy; 6) provide better tools for NGOs and governmental agencies working in communities impacted by climate change.
